info.title: Timeline
info.description: This feature allows an app to create and configure custom events that can show up in the timelines of certain CRM objects like contacts, companies, tickets, or deals. You'll find multiple use cases for this API in the sections below.
info.x-hubspot-api-use-case: After setting up a new set of sign-up flows on your website, update contact timelines to indicate which flow they completed. In each event, you could also include a link to open an iframe that displays additional external data about the event.
info.x-hubspot-introduction: Use the timeline events API to add custom event information to CRM record timelines. You'll first need to create a public app, then an event template to display event data.

get.description: This will take the `detailTemplate` from the event template and return an object rendering the specified event. If the template references `extraData` that isn't found in the event, it will be ignored and we'll render without it.

post.description: Creates an instance of a timeline event based on an event template. Once created, this event is immutable on the object timeline and cannot be modified. If the event template was configured to update object properties via `objectPropertyName`, this call will also attempt to updates those properties, or add them if they don't exist.

Do you wanna go on a walk?

put.summary: Updates an existing token on an event template
put.description: This will update the existing token on an event template. Name and type can't be changed on existing tokens.

parameters.name: appId
parameters.description: The ID of the target app.

delete.summary: Removes a token from the event template
delete.description:
This will remove the token from an existing template. Existing events and CRM objects will still retain the token and its mapped object properties, but new ones will not.

The timeline will still display this property for older CRM objects if it's still referenced in the template `Markdown`. New events will not.

Any lists or reports referencing deleted tokens will no longer return new contacts, but old ones will still exist in the lists.

parameters.name: appId
parameters.description: The ID of the target app.

get.description: This returns the previously created event. It contains all existing info for the event, but not necessarily the CRM object.

post.description: Creates multiple instances of timeline events based on an event template. Once created, these event are immutable on the object timeline and cannot be modified. If the event template was configured to update object properties via `objectPropertyName`, this call will also attempt to updates those properties, or add them if they don't exist.

get.summary: Renders the header or detail as HTML
get.description: This will take either the `headerTemplate` or `detailTemplate` from the event template and render for the specified event as HTML. If the template references `extraData` that isn't found in the event, it will be ignored and we'll render without it.

parameters.name: detail
parameters.description: Set to 'true', we want to render the `detailTemplate` instead of the `headerTemplate`.

get.summary: List all event templates for your app
get.description: Use this to list all event templates owned by your app.

parameters.name: appId
parameters.description: The ID of the target app.

results.name: PetSpot Registration

post.summary: Create an event template for your app
post.description:
Event templates define the general structure for a custom timeline event. This includes formatted copy for its heading and details, as well as any custom property definitions. The event could be something like viewing a video, registering for a webinar, or filling out a survey. A single app can define multiple event templates.

Event templates will be created for contacts by default, but they can be created for companies, tickets, and deals as well.

Each event template contains its own set of tokens and `Markdown` templates. These tokens can be associated with any CRM object properties via the `objectPropertyName` field to fully build out CRM objects.

You must create an event template before you can create events.

parameters.name: appId
parameters.description: The ID of the target app.

example.name: PetSpot Registration

get.summary: Gets a specific event template for your app
get.description: View the current state of a specific template and its tokens.

parameters.name: appId
parameters.description: The ID of the target app.

example.name: PetSpot Registration

put.description:
Updates an existing template and its tokens. This is primarily used to update the headerTemplate/detailTemplate, and those changes will take effect for existing events.

You can also update or replace all the tokens in the template here instead of doing individual API calls on the `/tokens` endpoint.

parameters.name: appId
parameters.description: The ID of the target app.

example.name: PetSpot Registration

delete.summary: Deletes an event template for the app
delete.description:
This will delete the event template. All associated events will be removed from search results and the timeline UI.

This action can't be undone, so it's highly recommended that you stop using any associated events before deleting a template.

parameters.name: appId
parameters.description: The ID of the target app.

post.summary: Adds a token to an existing event template
post.description:
Once you've defined an event template, it's likely that you'll want to define tokens for it as well. You can do this on the event template itself or update individual tokens here.

Event type tokens allow you to attach custom data to events displayed in a timeline or used for list segmentation.

You can also use `objectPropertyName` to associate any CRM object properties. This will allow you to fully build out CRM objects.

Token names should be unique across the template.

parameters.name: appId
parameters.description: The ID of the target app.

extraData.description: Additional event-specific data that can be interpreted by the template's markdown.

questions.question: Who's a good girl?
Do you wanna go on a walk?

domain.description: The event domain (often paired with utk).

tokens.description: A collection of token keys and values associated with the template tokens.

id.description: Identifier for the event. This is optional, and we recommend you do not pass this in. We will create one for you if you omit this. You can also use `{{uuid}}` anywhere in the ID to generate a unique string, guaranteeing uniqueness.

utk.description: Use the `utk` parameter to associate an event with a contact by `usertoken`. This is recommended if you don't know a user's email, but have an identifying user token in your cookie.

email.description: The email address used for contact-specific events. This can be used to identify existing contacts, create new ones, or change the email for an existing contact (if paired with the `objectId`).

objectId.description: The CRM object identifier. This is required for every event other than contacts (where utk or email can be used).

timestamp.description: The time the event occurred. If not passed in, the curren time will be assumed. This is used to determine where an event is shown on a CRM object's timeline.

TimelineEvent.description: The state of the timeline event.

linkLabel.description: The text displaying the link that will display the iframe.

headerLabel.description: The label of the modal window that displays the iframe contents.

width.description: The width of the modal window in pixels.

url.description: The URI of the iframe contents.

height.description: The height of the modal window in pixels.

subCategory.description: A specific category that contains more specific detail about the error

correlationId.description: A unique identifier for the request. Include this value with any error reports or support tickets

links.description: A map of link names to associated URIs containing documentation about the error or recommended remediation steps

message.description: A human readable message describing the error along with remediation steps where appropriate
message.example: Invalid input (details will vary based on the error)

detailTemplate.description: This uses Markdown syntax with Handlebars and event-specific data to render HTML on a timeline when you expand the details.

tokens.description: A collection of tokens that can be used as custom properties on the event and to create fully fledged CRM objects.

headerTemplate.description: This uses Markdown syntax with Handlebars and event-specific data to render HTML on a timeline as a header.

objectType.description: The type of CRM object this template is for. [Contacts, companies, tickets, and deals] are supported.

TimelineEventTemplateCreateRequest.description: State of the template definition being created.

createdAt.description: The date and time that the Event Template was created, as an ISO 8601 timestamp. Will be null if the template was created before Feb 18th, 2020.

detailTemplate.description: This uses Markdown syntax with Handlebars and event-specific data to render HTML on a timeline when you expand the details.

tokens.description: A collection of tokens that can be used as custom properties on the event and to create fully fledged CRM objects.

headerTemplate.description: This uses Markdown syntax with Handlebars and event-specific data to render HTML on a timeline as a header.

objectType.description: The type of CRM object this template is for. [Contacts, companies, tickets, and deals] are supported.

updatedAt.description: The date and time that the Event Template was last updated, as an ISO 8601 timestamp. Will be null if the template was created before Feb 18th, 2020.

TimelineEventTemplate.description: The current state of the template definition.

createdAt.description: The date and time that the Event Template Token was created, as an ISO 8601 timestamp. Will be null if the template was created before Feb 18th, 2020.

options.description: If type is `enumeration`, we should have a list of options to choose from.

name.description: The name of the token referenced in the templates. This must be unique for the specific template. It may only contain alphanumeric characters, periods, dashes, or underscores (. - _).

label.description: Used for list segmentation and reporting.

objectPropertyName.description: The name of the CRM object property. This will populate the CRM object property associated with the event. With enough of these, you can fully build CRM objects via the Timeline API.

type.description: The data type of the token. You can currently choose from [string, number, date, enumeration].

updatedAt.description: The date and time that the Event Template Token was last updated, as an ISO 8601 timestamp. Will be null if the template was created before Feb 18th, 2020.

extraData.description: Additional event-specific data that can be interpreted by the template's markdown.

domain.description: The event domain (often paired with utk).

tokens.description: A collection of token keys and values associated with the template tokens.

id.description: Identifier for the event. This should be unique to the app and event template. If you use the same ID for different CRM objects, the last to be processed will win and the first will not have a record. You can also use `{{uuid}}` anywhere in the ID to generate a unique string, guaranteeing uniqueness.

utk.description: Use the `utk` parameter to associate an event with a contact by `usertoken`. This is recommended if you don't know a user's email, but have an identifying user token in your cookie.

email.description: The email address used for contact-specific events. This can be used to identify existing contacts, create new ones, or change the email for an existing contact (if paired with the `objectId`).

objectId.description: The CRM object identifier. This is required for every event other than contacts (where utk or email can be used).

timestamp.description: The time the event occurred. If not passed in, the curren time will be assumed. This is used to determine where an event is shown on a CRM object's timeline.

objectType.description: The ObjectType associated with the EventTemplate.

TimelineEventResponse.description: The current state of the timeline event.

options.description: If type is `enumeration`, we should have a list of options to choose from.

label.description: Used for list segmentation and reporting.

objectPropertyName.description: The name of the CRM object property. This will populate the CRM object property associated with the event. With enough of these, you can fully build CRM objects via the Timeline API.

TimelineEventTemplateTokenUpdateRequest.description: State of the token definition for update requests.
